content.description: Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a mental health condition that develops after exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence. It is characterized by intrusive memories, avoidance of trauma reminders, negative changes in cognition and mood, and increased arousal. Symptoms persist for more than one month and cause significant distress or impairment.

acute_stress_disorder.description: Acute Stress Disorder (ASD) shares many symptoms with PTSD but occurs within 3 days to 1 month of trauma exposure. It includes intrusion, dissociation, avoidance, and arousal symptoms. If symptoms last beyond one month, PTSD may be diagnosed.
acute_stress_disorder.importance: Identifying ASD early allows for timely interventions that may reduce progression to PTSD.

complex_ptsd.description: Complex PTSD, recognized in ICD-11 but not in DSM-5, results from chronic or repeated trauma (e.g., long-term abuse, captivity). It includes PTSD symptoms plus disturbances in self-organization such as affect dysregulation, persistent negative self-concept, and difficulties in relationships.
complex_ptsd.note: Some individuals diagnosed with PTSD in DSM-5 may meet ICD-11 criteria for Complex PTSD, which can inform treatment planning.

mechanisms: Hyperactive amygdala leading to heightened fear and threat perception.
Reduced prefrontal cortex regulation over emotional responses.
Hippocampal volume reduction impairing memory contextualization.
Altered hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis function affecting stress hormone release.

content.diagnostic_criteria: Exposure to trauma via direct experience, witnessing, learning about events to close others, or repeated exposure to aversive details. Symptoms include intrusion, avoidance, negative alterations in cognition/mood, and changes in arousal/reactivity, persisting more than one month and causing significant distress/impairment.
content.prevalence: Lifetime prevalence around 6â€“8% in the general population, higher in high-risk groups (combat veterans, assault survivors).
content.age_of_onset: Can occur at any age; higher risk in adolescence and early adulthood after trauma.
content.prognosis: Early treatment and social support improve outcomes; untreated PTSD can become chronic and debilitating.

history: Detailed trauma history, including type, timing, and severity.
Symptom onset, duration, and functional impact.
medical_workup: Rule out neurological injury or medical causes of symptoms.

intrusion: Recurrent, intrusive memories of the trauma.
Strong distress or physical reactions to trauma cues.
avoidance: Avoiding thoughts, feelings, or conversations about the trauma.
Avoiding places, people, or activities related to the trauma.
negative_alterations_in_cognition_and_mo: Persistent negative beliefs about oneself or the world.
Distorted self-blame or blame of others.
Persistent negative emotions such as fear, guilt, or shame.
Feeling detached or estranged from others.

biological: Genetic vulnerability to anxiety or mood disorders.
Female sex (higher risk in epidemiological studies).

impact_on_life.school_work: Reduced performance, concentration issues, and absenteeism.
impact_on_life.social: Avoidance of gatherings, social withdrawal, and relationship strain.
impact_on_life.medical: Increased risk of substance abuse, cardiovascular problems, and chronic pain.

medications: SSRIs such as sertraline and paroxetine.
care_coordination: Involving family or trusted supports when appropriate.
Coordination between mental health and primary care providers.

treatment_goals: Restore functioning and quality of life.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Attributing symptoms to depression or generalized anxiety without exploring trauma history.
Underreporting due to stigma or avoidance.
overdiagnosis_factors: Diagnosing PTSD for normal acute stress reactions before one month has passed.

specifiers.with_delayed_expression: Onset of full criteria at least 6 months after the event.

adults: Emotional numbing, strained relationships, reduced work performance.

real_life_examples: A survivor of assault avoids leaving home and has daily flashbacks for years.
A combat veteran becomes hypervigilant and avoids crowded public spaces.
A car accident victim experiences nightmares and avoids driving long after the event.
